author: By Keith Bradsher and Joy Dong
title: What China’s E.V. City Says About the State of the Economy
description: Hefei has led the country in making electric vehicles and other tech products, but it still has not escaped a nationwide housing crisis.
content: Ultramodern factories churn out electric cars and solar panels in Hefei, an industrial center in the heart of central China. Broad avenues link office towers and landscaped parks. Subway lines open at a brisk pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Vince McMahon Cuts W.W.E. Ties After Sex Trafficking Accusation
description: The co-founder of World Wrestling Entertainment stepped down from its parent company’s board one day after an ex-employee accused him of sexual assault in a lawsuit.
content: Vince McMahon, the longtime chairman and former chief executive of World Wrestling Entertainment, resigned from the board of W.W.E.’s parent company on Friday, one day after a former employee accused him of sexual assault and sex trafficking in a lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler and Vivienne Walt
title: The Key Issues for Business in a Likely Trump-Biden Rematch
description: Clean energy investments, trade policy and more than one kind of uncertainty could be on the line.
content: After beating Nikki Haley in New Hampshire on Tuesday, Donald Trump  reaffirmed his position as the leading candidate to win the Republican nomination. That has business leaders facing the possibility of another Trump presidency, and their investors trying to figure out what it could mean for their bottom lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Petrow and Derek Arthur
title: My Sister Chose the Day She Wanted to Die
description: In the face of terminal illness, medical aid in dying should be a right.
content: Should terminally ill people be able to choose how they die? Six years after being diagnosed with advanced ovarian cancer, Julie Petrow-Cohen decided to use medical aid in dying — or MAID, as it is often called — to end her life. But for many Americans in similar circumstances, this is not an option. In this audio essay, the writer Steven Petrow shares the story of his sister’s last day and why MAID should be a right for everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: More Than 100 Animals Seized From Long Island Home
description: Animal welfare authorities say the animals were being illegally held and included a South American ostrich, a giant African snail, two prairie dogs and an endangered tiger salamander.
content: Animal welfare authorities seized more than 100 animals from a Long Island home this week — including a South American ostrich, a giant African snail, two prairie dogs and an endangered tiger salamander — after a tip they received about exotic animals led them to their owner’s doorstep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim, Julian E. Barnes, Aaron Boxerman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Major Donors Pause Funding for U.N. Agency as Scandal Widens
description: The actions came as specific, “horrific” details were more widely shared by the U.N. and Israel.
content: Germany, Britain and at least four other countries said Saturday they were suspending funding for the United Nations agency that provides food, water and essential services for Palestinian civilians in the Gaza Strip, many of whom have been described as being on the brink of starvation after 16 weeks of war between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Hate Kids. Do I Have to Make Nice With My Nephew?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to manage relationships with loved ones you don’t really like.
content: My only sibling is an (exhausted) single parent of one son. I have always disliked being around children and know I never want any of my own (or near me). I feel pressure from my sibling and family to form a relationship with the child. I’ve been directly asked to entertain or spend time with him, despite my lack of interest or ease in doing so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Raja Abdulrahim, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
title: U.N. Court Orders Israel to Prevent Genocide, but Does Not Demand Stop to War
description: The top United Nations court in The Hague did not rule on whether Israel was committing genocide in Gaza, the accusation that South Africa brought before the court.
content: The United Nations’ highest court said on Friday that Israel must take action to prevent acts of genocide by its forces in the Gaza Strip, adding to the international pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to reduce death and destruction in the battered Palestinian enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Bali Bombing Conspirators Get 5 More Years at Guantánamo Bay
description: A military jury sentenced two Malaysian men to 23 years for helping perpetrators of the bombing that killed 202 people, but a side deal reduced the punishment.
content: A military jury at Guantánamo Bay sentenced two prisoners to 23 years in confinement on Friday for conspiring in the 2002 terrorist bombing that killed 202 people in Bali, Indonesia. But the men could be freed by 2029 under a secret deal and with sentencing credit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Chips as Chicken and Wings as Dip
description: Sour cream and onion chicken, Buffalo chicken dip and bulgogi-style tofu make for some fun flip-flops.
content: Today’s newsletter is all about recipes that take the flavors of one beloved food and apply them to something else, creating a dish that’s both familiar and novel. What can we say? It’s the end of January, we’re a little stir-crazy and we love a bit of fun in the kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Spending More Money on Police Shows No Clear Link to Lower Crime Levels
description: A study led by researchers in Toronto found that crime had risen in several cities along with increases in spending.
content: One effect we’re now seeing from the inflation that is largely a product of the pandemic and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine are municipal tax increases on a scale that was politically unimaginable not long ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: New Jersey Political Races, Often Raucous, Are Bananas This Year
description: A Republican state senator announced a run for governor, joining a dizzying array of high-profile races playing out under extraordinary circumstances.
content: New Jersey’s first lady is running for U.S. Senate. A former governor who resigned in disgrace is trying to make a political comeback, as a mayor. Two members of Congress and a half-dozen other political luminaries are preparing to campaign for governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Unboxing Thousands of Photos of New York City in the ’70s and ’80s
description: Arlene Gottfried, a sister of the late comedian Gilbert Gottfried, memorialized a grittier era of the city. Now her family wants to share her collection with the world.
content: A nondescript locker in a Lower Manhattan storage center is a portal to a New York City still plagued by crack, AIDS and rampant crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maxwell Gillmer
title: A Tender Debut Novel About the Beauty and Pain of First Love
description: In “How We Named the Stars,” a young, queer student in mourning recounts the tale of a pivotal romance.
content: Andrés N. Ordorica’s debut novel, “How We Named the Stars,” begins with a crushing declaration: “Sam’s dead.” It’s an opening that colors everything to come, introducing a loss that will reverberate across every page of this meditative and tender book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: After Carroll Verdict, Haley Says ‘America Can Do Better’ Than Trump or Biden
description: As Trump campaign surrogates defended the former president in light of an $83.3 million defamation verdict, Nikki Haley said his legal troubles continued to be a distraction.
content: Nikki Haley criticized Donald J. Trump on Friday, saying, “America can do better than Donald Trump and Joe Biden,” after a Manhattan jury had ordered the former president to pay $83.3 million for defaming the writer E. Jean Carroll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: When a Neighbor Dies Unattended, How Should the Building Handle It?
description: In situations where people have died and their estate is in court, fixing a problem in their former apartment is legally complex.
content: Q: Six months ago, while I was out of town, there were two unattended deaths in my 60-unit co-op building in Brooklyn. The bodies were eventually discovered and removed. My apartment is above the unit where this occurred, and I returned to flies and a smelly apartment. Two months later, the co-op board got a court order allowing it to break the NYPD seal and remove the apartment’s contents. But the smell remains, and no work is planned. The odor is weaker now, but persistent, especially when the heat comes on. It’s too cold to keep the windows open. I’m running air purifiers, but have had to abandon one room and all the closets. My household insurance won’t help, because there is no physical damage. What recourse do I have?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Healy
title: My Life as a Neighborhood Crank
description: When you have no job, and too much time on your hands, the little things begin to grate.
content: On a hot Tuesday afternoon, a German shepherd met my gaze as he emptied his bowels on the Brooklyn sidewalk. The man holding the leash was large and bald and wearing a tank top. As he turned to walk away, I shot him a look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Edward Wong
title: How Leaders and Diplomats Are Trying to End the Gaza War
description: Top American, Israeli and Arab officials are seeking to forge three parallel but related deals that could end the war in Gaza, finalize its postwar status, and, most ambitiously, set commitments for the creation of a Palestinian state.
content: Top officials from at least 10 different administrations are trying to forge a head-spinning set of deals to end the Gaza war and answer the divisive question of how the territory will be governed after the fighting stops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How Frankie Grande Spends His Sundays
description: The actor, singer and reality TV personality fills his day with video games, comfort food with friends and a teary trip to the movies.
content: Frankie Grande likes to stay busy — even on Sundays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang, Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
title: China Acknowledges Imprisoning a British Man on Spy Charges
description: A businessman who had worked in China for decades vanished from view in 2018, but his fate had been unknown, and publicly unremarked upon, until now.
content: A British businessman who disappeared from public view in China in 2018 was sentenced to five years in prison in 2022, China’s Foreign Ministry said on Friday, in its first public acknowledgment of the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: State Dept. Tells Congress It Has Approved Sale of F-16 Jets to Turkey
description: The department received documents on Friday signed by Turkey’s leader approving Sweden’s long-delayed entry into NATO. The alliance now awaits word from the lone holdout, Hungary.
content: The State Department notified Congress on Friday that it had approved a $23 billion sale of F-16 fighter jets and related equipment to Turkey after the country’s leader signed documents to allow Sweden’s long-delayed entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, department officials and the Pentagon said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Tariq Panja
title: FIFA Convictions Are Imperiled by Questions of U.S. Overreach
description: Two Supreme Court decisions and a lower court’s ruling have cast doubt on the legal basis for a host of prosecutions. Several defendants want their records cleared and their money back.
content: Nearly a decade after police officers marched world soccer officials out of a luxury hotel in Zurich at dawn, revealing a corruption scandal that shook the world’s most popular sport, the case is at risk of falling apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Ogre Gorging on America
description: Trump gives the bitchiest victory speech ever.
content: If you can imagine the lobby bar of the Manchester Marriott as an Anglo-Saxon mead hall, I can explain how it felt to cover the New Hampshire primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Must Campaign Against a Man Who Already Thinks He’s President
description: President Biden, the man actually in the White House, faces a conundrum: How do you run against a man who never conceded his election loss, and is already acting like he has the job?
content: He promised to repeal the Affordable Care Act. He demanded states deploy the National Guard to the U.S.-Mexico border. He warned congressional Republicans to hold out for a perfect deal on immigration — or else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Democrats Say Biden Hasn’t ‘Made the Case’ on Climate Despite Achievements
description: The president likes to talk about his climate agenda as an opportunity to create jobs. Polling shows that may be the wrong way to win over voters.
content: President Biden has done more than any president to tackle climate change, but strategists are grappling with an uncomfortable fact: Voters don’t seem to know it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: The Choreographer Wore Pointe Shoes
description: Tiler Peck, a New York City Ballet star, is making her first work for the company. “It’s my opportunity to pass on to the next generation anything that’s been given to me.”
content: During rehearsals for New York City Ballet’s winter season, there was something very unusual about one of the choreographers creating a new dance. It wasn’t just that the person in charge was a woman, though that would have been uncommon until a few years ago. Nor was it that the choreographer, Tiler Peck, was one of the company’s star ballerinas, though that is still quite rare. The difference was what Peck wore on her feet as she made and rehearsed the work: pointe shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: London’s Highline Will Echo Its New York Inspiration, With Local Notes
description: Hoping to repeat the success of Manhattan’s park, London is transforming a disused rail line, elevated 25 feet above the city’s streets, into its own floating green space.
content: The derelict rail bridge stretches across a busy north London street, green foliage peeking out of the gaps between the beams overhead, where bright blue paint flakes from rusting steel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Charles Fried, Legal Scholar Who Broke With Conservatives, Dies at 88
description: As solicitor general under Reagan, he argued against abortion rights and affirmative action. But he came to see the current Supreme Court as “reactionary, not conservative.”
content: Charles Fried, a conservative legal scholar who as President Ronald Reagan’s solicitor general argued against abortion rights and affirmative action before the Supreme Court — but who later rejected the conservative legal movement’s rightward march, calling the current high court “reactionary” — died on Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Has History of Friction With U.N. Agency for Palestinians
description: Palestinians see UNRWA as an essential lifeline for millions of descendants of refugees. In Israel, however, many see the agency as an obstacle to resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
content: Israel’s accusations against 12 employees of the U.N. aid agency for Palestinians, the main aid operation in Gaza, are the latest episode of a decades-long friction between Israel and the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie J. M. Baker
title: Like Nora Ephron, With a British Twist
description: In her second novel, “Good Material,” Dolly Alderton adds her own flair to the classic rom-com.
content: Andy, the 35-year-old struggling comedian who narrates most of Dolly Alderton’s new novel, “Good Material,” has been freshly dumped by his ex, Jen, for mysterious reasons. Like Rob in Nick Hornby’s “High Fidelity,” an obvious inspiration, Andy knows his relationship had its problems. He’s even compiled a list of Jen’s faults, including “lingered too long in museums” where he “once saw her nod respectfully at a TINY JADE SPOON.” It doesn’t soothe his heartbreak; Andy is obsessed with working out what went wrong. In the process, maybe he can get to the bottom of why the rest of his life has derailed, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Dobbs Overturned Much More Than Roe v. Wade
description: Lawmakers in Tennessee, Oklahoma and other Republican states want to turn the clock back to the 19th century.
content: Most of my writing this week was on the recent elections in Iowa and New Hampshire, but most of my reading was focused elsewhere. In particular, I want to highlight this report from Jessica Valenti, published in her excellent newsletter, on proposed travel bans for abortion care in Tennessee and Oklahoma. The Tennessee ban, proposed by State Representative Jason Zachary, would make it a felony to take a minor out of state to obtain an abortion. As Valenti notes, “That means a friend, aunt or grandmother who helps a teenager get an abortion could be sent to prison for 15 years.” The Oklahoma bill, if signed into law, would punish anyone who helped a minor obtain abortion care with up to five years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: When Soccer’s Content Mine Loses Sight of Reality
description: As documentaries and series about teams proliferate, it’s easy to pine for the ones that offered the clearest windows into the game.
content: Being early, Marc Andreessen once ruefully said, is the same as being wrong. Admittedly, Andreesen, the software engineer, angel investor and all-purpose Silicon Valley maven, deployed the maxim in the context of his own somewhat bitter experiences in the world of cloud computing, but it works surprisingly well as an analysis of “Being: Liverpool.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Kellen Browning
title: In Las Vegas, Trump turns his focus back to Biden.
description: At a rally in Nevada, a key battleground state, Donald Trump sought to pivot to a general election message. A mile away, Vice President Kamala Harris framed the election as a battle for democracy.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has been itching for months to focus on a likely matchup between him and President Biden in November, previewed on Saturday a likely general-election message, extensively attacking Mr. Biden at an event in Nevada, a critical battleground state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: On Holocaust Memorial Day, Germans Rally Against Far Right and for Democracy
description: Large crowds have protested since it was revealed that members of the far-right Alternative for Germany party had met with neo-Nazis and those calling for a mass deportation.
content: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets across Germany on Holocaust Memorial Day on Saturday to demonstrate in support of democracy and against the rise of a far-right party, the Alternative for Germany, or AfD, which is on track to make political gains in state elections this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: A Famed Analyst’s Final Forecast Is the Fall of the U.S. Economy
description: Dick Bove, the ubiquitous banking expert, is going out swinging after more than half a century in the business.
content: Over his 54 years as a financial analyst, Richard X. Bove perfected the art of grabbing attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: How Some Families Are Breaking the Rules to Apply for Financial Aid
description: Experts are already encouraging students and parents to exchange usernames and passwords to expedite aid applications. One problem: It’s not legal.
content: Here’s the good news: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or FAFSA, website is now open 24 hours a day, seven days a week after a yearslong effort to simplify the process of seeking financial assistance. This month, I watched two high school seniors and their college counselor start the forms from scratch and submit them in just over an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: A Drug Test Cost a D.E.A. Agent His Job. He Sued, and Got It Back.
description: A longtime counternarcotics agent said he used CBD for chronic pain, considering it safer than opioids. The choice set off a legal fight.
content: The Drug Enforcement Administration regarded Anthony L. Armour as an “outstanding” special agent on the front lines of the nation’s opioid epidemic. But in 2019, a routine drug test derailed his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: Gordon Ramsay Isn’t Going Anywhere
description: With a new season of his series “Next Level Chef,” reality TV’s most enduring antihero still reigns supreme. How long can he keep it up?
content: Gordon Ramsay insists he never wanted to be the bad boy. His image as the brash, bellicose chef and restaurateur, as the master of the culinary meltdown, was, he said, largely a matter of getting off on the wrong foot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Negotiators Close In on Hostage Deal That Would Halt Fighting in Gaza for Weeks
description: A written draft agreement calls for the phased release of captives held by Hamas in exchange for a cessation in Israel’s military offensive for about two months.
content: American-led negotiators are edging closer to an agreement in which Israel would suspend its war in Gaza for about two months in exchange for the release of more than 100 hostages still held by Hamas, a deal that could be sealed in the next two weeks and would transform the conflict consuming the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Joy and Sorrow of Streaming
description: Streaming offers an infinity of choice. It also offers the illusion that we’ll find the perfect cinematic solution to whatever is ailing us.
content: The year continues to get its bearings, to establish itself. Right now, it’s still a collection of post-holiday weeks, getting-going weeks, weeks for planning the year to come. An on-ramp where we get up to speed. Soon we’ll be properly in the flow of traffic, soon we’ll really be on our way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Washington Man Pleads Guilty to Making Numerous ‘Swatting’ Calls
description: Ashton Connor Garcia, who called himself a “cyberterrorist,” made 20 calls about fake bombs, shootings and other threats that drew police responses, officials said.
content: A man in Washington State has pleaded guilty to federal charges stemming from several hoax calls he made to law enforcement agencies in which he falsely reported bombs, shootings and other threats that sometimes led police officers to enter victims’ homes with their weapons drawn, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Ukraine Criticizes HBO, Saying New ‘White Lotus’ Actor Supports War
description: On social media, Ukraine’s foreign ministry posted clips of the Serbian actor Milos Bikovic receiving a medal for cultural achievement from Vladimir Putin in 2018.
content: Ukraine’s foreign ministry criticized HBO this week after Milos Bikovic was cast in the third season of “The White Lotus,” saying without evidence that the Serbian actor had supported Russia since its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Tiny Scrap
description: Grace and Greg Warrington make their New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Woman Charged With Hiding Corpse Over Body Parts Found in Refrigerator
description: Heather Stines told the police the head, arms and legs belonged to a man her husband had killed in September, according to court records.
content: A Brooklyn woman was charged this week with concealing a human corpse after the police found a head and other body parts in garbage bags stuffed in her refrigerator, officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: A ‘Corpsicle’ Came Back to Life on ‘True Detective.’ Is That Possible?
description: An incident involving a group of frozen bodies on the fourth season of the HBO series has raised some scientific questions.
content: The men lay frozen naked in a ghoulish pile, with mouths agape and eyes glazed over, their hair encrusted with ice and snow. They were all dead — or so the investigators on the HBO series “True Detective: Night Country” thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian J. O'Connor
title: January Is Nearly Over. Have You Done Your Retirement Review?
description: While 2024 is still new, assessing where you stand in some key areas of personal finance can help smooth the transition to your later years.
content: The crash diets have crashed, the brand-new budgets won’t budge and your Peloton is now the world’s most expensive laundry rack. But even if every one of your New Year’s resolutions is toast, there’s still one start-of-the-year chore you would be wise to handle: your retirement review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Netanyahu’s Cynical Political Game
description: He has managed to alienate Israel’s most important allies.
content: It has become clear that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is not the leader for this critical moment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 27, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 27, 2024.
content: An article on Dec. 31 about details showing a pattern of rape, mutilation and extreme brutality against women in the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas on Israel misstated the age of Sapir, the woman who has become one of the Israeli police’s key witnesses to the attack. She is 26, not 24.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac, Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: Los Angeles Times Owner Clashed With Top Editor Over Unpublished Article
description: The owner, Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong, had raised concerns with Kevin Merida, who stepped down this month, over reporting about a wealthy doctor and his dog.
content: When Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong, the billionaire owner of The Los Angeles Times, hired Kevin Merida to be the newspaper’s top editor nearly three years ago, he hailed the journalist as someone who would maintain the publication’s high standards and journalistic integrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Harry Connick Sr., New Orleans D.A. Criticized for Overreach, Dies at 97
description: The city’s top prosecutor from 1973 to 2003, he led an office that sent hundreds of Black men to prison and became known for its record of wrongful convictions.
content: Harry Connick Sr., a long-serving district attorney in New Orleans whose office gained national notoriety for prosecutorial overreach that eventually resulted in many reversed convictions, died on Thursday at his home in New Orleans. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should SATs Be Optional?
description: Readers discuss an article by David Leonhardt about research showing the tests’ usefulness.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne, Alina Lobzina and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: A Collective ‘No’: Anti-Putin Russians Embrace an Unlikely Challenger
description: Long lines have popped up in Russia and beyond to get Boris B. Nadezhdin, an antiwar candidate, onto the ballot for Russia’s presidential election in March.
content: His surname comes from the Russian word for hope — and for hundreds of thousands of antiwar Russians, that is, improbably enough, what he has become.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Hammer Time
description: Nathan Hasegawa’s second puzzle is a hit.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Madden
title: When Going Off Message Is the Message
description: Reneé Rapp has been going off-script on the press circuit for “Mean Girls.” Maybe she lacks media training — and maybe that’s the point.
content: On her press tour for the new adaptation of “Mean Girls,” Reneé Rapp has called out the owner of a bus touring company owner by name, described herself as “ageist” against millennial women, praised Megan Thee Stallion’s butt and used an interview as an opportunity to shoot her shot with Rachel McAdams, the original Regina George, whose shoes Ms. Rapp stepped into for her latest role. She also said that she might not want Ms. McAdams to see the new take on the character and suggested that she was weary of the franchise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Jake Johnson Likes to Play the Hollywood Game, Especially When It Changes
description: “When you get on this roller coaster, you don’t know how long you’re going to be allowed to play while you’re here,” the “New Girl” actor said about his filmmaking debut, “Self Reliance.”
content: If you were bored enough — a stultifying job, living with Mom after a bad breakup — you, too, might climb into a mysterious limo carrying Andy Samberg. You might even consider the offer: outwit assassins for 30 days and win $1 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: What Worries Me About War With China After My Visit to Taiwan
description: Some well-meaning U.S. efforts to help Taiwan may end up provoking China when we should be trying to lower tensions.
content: Michael Mullen, the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is concerned enough about the risk of war between the United States and China that he is listening to the audiobook version of Barbara Tuchman’s “The Guns of August,” the classic history of how the major powers in 1914 stumbled into World War I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Kat Von D Wins Copyright Trial Over Miles Davis Tattoo
description: The photographer who took the portrait of the jazz artist Miles Davis, which inspired the tattoo, had filed a lawsuit based on copyright infringement.
content: Kat Von D, a celebrity tattoo artist, won a legal battle in federal court on Friday when a jury ruled unanimously that her reproduction of a photo of the celebrated jazz musician Miles Davis in a tattoo did not violate copyright law.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books That Wring Every Ounce From Their Story Lines
description: An editor recommends an Irish novel about a banker in trouble and a Swiss novel about schoolgirl obsession.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: A Radical Proposal for Nikki Haley: Try to Win More Votes
description: There’s no reason to imitate Chris Christie and Liz Cheney just yet.
content: Nikki Haley lost the New Hampshire primary but found a cause: getting under Donald Trump’s not exactly rhinoceros-thick skin. The story of the Republican primary campaign in the days since Trump’s victory has been one where the victor acts like a sore loser and the likely loser loosens up, goads her stronger rival and finds a pool of small-dollar donors to keep her in the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Prosecutors in Nashville Drop Charges Against Chris Young
description: The country singer had been charged with disorderly conduct, assaulting an officer and resisting arrest after an altercation at a downtown bar.
content: Prosecutors on Friday dropped all charges that had been brought against the country music singer Chris Young in connection with an altercation with an Alcoholic Beverage Commission agent at a Nashville bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Kate Christobek
title: In Trump’s Bitter, Yearslong Brawl with Roberta Kaplan, He Keeps Losing
description: When they faced off at E. Jean Carroll’s defamation trial, it was a clash of two New Yorkers, both formidable combatants and talkers, but products of different worlds.
content: The meeting turned ugly fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda McCracken
title: Is It a Crush or Have You Fallen Into Limerence?
description: How an intense longing for a romantic connection can lead to a serious addiction.
content: For most people, crushes come and go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: The Words to Say It
description: What it means to have words — and to lose them.
content: In Gaza and beyond, what it means to have words — and to lose them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Djokovic’s Perfection Finally Comes to End Against Italy’s Sinner
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 27, 2024.
content: “I didn’t feel really myself on the court during this tournament.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Nikki Haley Was Target of December ‘Swatting’ Incident, Authorities Say
description: The Republican presidential candidate was not home at the time of the episode on Dec. 30, one of several targeting politicians late last year, Reuters reported.
content: A bogus account of a shooting at a South Carolina home owned by Nikki Haley sent the authorities scrambling in late December, but the Republican presidential candidate and a former governor of the state, was not there at the time, Reuters reported on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Ofri
title: My Patients Used to Be Gung-Ho About the Covid Vaccine. What Changed?
description: A newer, more vague vaccine hesitancy is emerging. A New York doctor has some advice for how to stop it.
content: The response has been almost like clockwork, at nearly every medical visit in the last few weeks. “It’s time for the flu shot,” I’ll say to my patients, “plus the updated Covid vaccine.” And that’s when the groans start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: The S&P 500 Through the Prism of a ‘Magnificent 7’
description: Seven tech stocks, including Meta, Nvidia and Apple, have accounted for roughly 90 percent of the S&P’s gains over the past 12 months.
content: Seven tech stocks, including Meta, Nvidia and Apple, have accounted for roughly 90 percent of the S&P’s gains over the past 12 months.
source.name: The New York Times
